projectDesc.p: "The Prologue to the Book of Histories" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Ci comence li prologue ou livre des estoires, et la porsivance.
app.rdg: Here begins the prologue to the book of histories, and what follows.
Lords, I have heard it said

app.lem: C'on doit adès bien dire et faire
app.rdg: That one must always speak and act well

app.lem: Tant con on ou siecle demore
app.rdg: For as long as one remains in the world.

app.lem: Li hom ne vit c'une sole ore,
app.rdg: A man lives but a single hour

app.lem: Ainz trespasse et va a la fin,
app.rdg: Before dying and going to his end.

app.lem: S'il a eü vrai cuer et fin,
app.rdg: If he has had a true and pure heart,

app.lem: Que s'uevre ait esté bone et fine;
app.rdg: And his work has been good and pure,

app.lem: A cel segnor qui tot afine

app.rdg: He has as great a reward

app.lem: En a la desserte si grande

app.rdg: As his heart wants and asks for

app.lem: Com ses cuers le veut e demande;

app.rdg: from that Lord who brings everything to its end.

app.lem: Car c'est li sires qui tot rent
app.rdg: For the Lord returns everything
That one does for him so fairly

app.lem: Que ja ne s'en devra nus plaindre.
app.rdg: That one must never complain;

app.lem: Por quoi ne se doit nus hom faindre
app.rdg: For this reason, one must not make a pretence

app.lem: De lui servir a son pooir:
app.rdg: Of serving him to the best of one’s ability:

app.lem: Metre i doit on sens et voloir.
app.rdg: One must put meaning and intention into it.

app.lem: Qui si le fai sauve iert sa paine,
app.rdg: Whoever acts thus will have his pains guaranteed

app.lem: Quar qui por bon segnor si paine
app.rdg: For whoever troubles himself for the good Lord

app.lem: En la fin en a tel merite
app.rdg: Has such reward for it at the end
That it is greatly to his advantage;

app.lem: Et qui siert a mauvais segnor
app.rdg: And whoever serves the lord badly

app.lem: Il n'i a ni preu ni honor;
app.rdg: Has neither profit nor honour.

app.lem: De ce seit sa pensée certe,
app.rdg: May he be certain of this:

app.lem: Ja ne s'en tornera sanz perte.
app.rdg: He will never get away without a loss.
The bad lord is the devil

app.lem: Qui point ne nos est profitables,
app.rdg: Who is not useful to us at all

app.lem: Car il het raison et mesure,
app.rdg:
Because he hates truth and self-restraint,
‘Raison’ can mean both what is true and what is just.
‘Mesure’ is an important virtue in medieval culture and can be variously translated as moderation, restraint, reason or good judgement.

Goodness, loyalty and justice.
‘Droiture’ means moral or legal rectitude as well as fairness or justice.
He has many servants and yet

app.lem: Qu'il le servent a son talent,
app.rdg: If they serve him as he desires,

app.lem: E! las, dolent que feront ils?
app.rdg: Alas! what will those miserable ones do?
Their prize will be exile,
Eternal pain and misery;
They leave Lord God, the true father,
And hold fast to the Enemy.

app.lem: S[e] il ont si mauvais ami
app.rdg: If they are to have such a bad friend,

app.lem: Meaus lor venist que né ne fussent,
app.rdg: It would have been better for them that they hadn’t been born,

app.lem: Car ne font pas ce qu'il deüssent.
app.rdg: For they are not doing what they should.
They were called Christians
When they were reborn

app.lem: Ens en sains fons, si com il devrent
app.rdg:
In the holy font, doing as they ought to,
This is a reference to the Christian sacrament of baptism.

app.lem: E l'uile et la cresme recevrent
app.rdg:
And received the oil and the chrism;
Chrism is a consecrated oil used in the administration of certain Catholic sacraments, including baptism.

app.lem: La orent il a Deu covenent
app.rdg: There they addressed a covenant to God
That they would steadfastly believe in him
And that they would always serve him
And follow his commands.

app.lem: Por Deu! segnor, s'il ne le font,
app.rdg: By God, Lords, if they don’t do it,
Do you know what reward they will have?
They will have disobeyed;
If this isn't amended by penitence,
They will have lost the land
Which is called Paradise.
May you always remember Adam,

app.lem: Qui en dolor et en ahan
app.rdg: Who gave us sorrow and suffering

app.lem: Nos mist par le mors d'une pome.
app.rdg: With the bite of an apple.
Lords, Adam, this first man,
Had been formed and shaped by our Lord
In his image,

app.lem: E si l'ot mis en paradis
app.rdg: And then he put him in Paradise

app.lem: Ou il eüst esté toz dis
app.rdg: Where he would have been for evermore
If he hadn’t ignored his command,
For which reason we suffer still.
By the command that he broke

app.lem: Ens el pas de la mort passa;
app.rdg:
He became mortal;
The text literally states that he entered into proximity of death.

app.lem: C'en fi mis ens en la paine
app.rdg: He was made to suffer the punishment
Which every man and woman suffers.

app.lem: Seignor, et puis qu'Adans fu mis
app.rdg: Lords, since Adam was put

app.lem: Por el fait hors du paradis,
app.rdg: Out of Paradise because of this act,

app.lem: Qu'iert il de nos qui chascun jor
app.rdg: How will it be for us, who every day
Anger the Lord a hundred times —
The Lord who became angry at Adam
For a single command that he disobeyed?
We ought to remember this well,
But we let things simply turn out

app.lem: La choze si come puet estre:
app.rdg: as they are wont to do.

app.lem: Ne creons mès ni cler ni prestre
app.rdg: We believe neither cleric nor priest
Although they can tell us the truth.

The world grows worse every day:
‘Siecles’ means both the world and the age; it is sometimes also used in the Middle Ages to mean ‘century’, following the Roman usage of ‘seculum’ (and in line with the modern French usage of ‘siècle’).

app.lem: C'est grans dolors et grans tristece.
app.rdg: It’s a great misery and a great sadness.

app.lem: Chascuns de bien fere a perece,
app.rdg: Everyone is lazy about acting well

app.lem: Ne nus ne redoute la mort
app.rdg: And does not fear the death

app.lem: Que si aigrement pince et mort
app.rdg: That so painfully pinches and bites

app.lem: Que la dolor ne puet descrire
app.rdg: That no saint — male or female — can describe the pain,

app.lem: Sains ni sainte, tant sache dire.
app.rdg: however much they can tell us.
It’s an extraordinary thing that we do not fear

app.lem: Ce qu'a nos propres oils veons:
app.rdg: What we see with our own eyes:

app.lem: C'est ce que la more aprochomes,
app.rdg: That we approach death
And will accompany our bodies

app.lem: As vers de terre sans orgoill.
app.rdg: To meet the worms without pride.
We will wear but a single shroud
As clothing.

Lords, wouldn’t it be reasonable
‘Mesure’, as previously noted, is an important virtue in medieval culture and can be variously translated as moderation, restraint, reason or good judgement.
For us to reflect on ourselves
And abandon our evil ways?

app.lem: Que vaut force, que vaut noblece?
app.rdg: What is strength worth? What is nobility worth?

app.lem: Que vaut beautés, que vaut richece?
app.rdg: What is beauty worth? What are riches worth?
What is high status or noble extraction worth?

app.lem: Certes, li hom n'est mie sages

app.rdg: Certainly the man who places his trust in all of these

app.lem: Qui en tout ce a sa fiance,

app.rdg: Is not wise at all,

app.lem: Car il n'i a fors trespassance.
app.rdg: For there is nothing there but death.

app.lem: N'en dirai plus: el ai a faire,
app.rdg: I will say no more; I have much to do,

app.lem: Car j'ai entrepris un a faire
app.rdg: For I have undertaken to present a matter
Following what is written

app.lem: Ou mout avra sens et mesure.
app.rdg:
In which there will be much meaning and good judgement.
‘Mesure’, as previously noted, is an important virtue in medieval culture and can be variously translated as moderation, restraint, reason or good judgement.
Whoever follows the content
And listens from the heart

app.lem: Oïr porra la plus haute ovre
app.rdg: Will be able to hear the worthiest work

app.lem: Qui encor pas ne si descuevre

app.rdg: Ever presented in our language:

app.lem: C'onques fust en nos lenge traite.

app.rdg: A work which is still unknown.
But I haven’t yet mentioned
Where, or with whom, I will begin.

app.lem: Or fetes pais, jel vos dirai.
app.rdg: Now be silent and I will tell you.

app.lem: De Deu est bon li comenciers:
app.rdg: It is right to begin with God.
I will start with him first:
How he formed and made Adam,
How he put him in Paradise,

app.lem: E com Adans entra en paine,
app.rdg: And why Adam began to suffer —

app.lem: Por quoi nos vestons dras de laine,
app.rdg: For which reason we wear wool cloth;
How Adam had descendants
Who covered the earth.

app.lem: N'i lairai riens que d'oir en oir
app.rdg: I will not omit anything that

app.lem: Ne doie dire a mon pooir,
app.rdg: I ought to tell to the best of my ability, without fault,
Going from generation to generation until the flood.
After that I will not be in any doubt;
I must tell of Noah:

app.lem: Quels hom il fu, de quel afaire,
app.rdg: What kind of man he was, what he did,

app.lem: De ses enfans, de lor lignage
app.rdg: About his children, and their lineage,

app.lem: Ou il out maint prodome e sage
app.rdg: Of which many were noble and wise

app.lem: E maint felon e maint mauvais.
app.rdg: And many cruel, and many bad.
Before the book is done [I will tell]:
How the lands divided
And moved apart and separated,

app.lem: E qui funda la tor Babel,
app.rdg: And who built the Tower of Babel;

app.lem: De Babiloine et dou roi Bel,
app.rdg: About Babylon and King Bel,
About other famous cities;
About the regions and countries

app.lem: E des isles qui sunt en mer.
app.rdg: And the islands in the sea.

app.lem: Pou en i lairai a nomer,
app.rdg: There is little I will refrain from saying about them
If it should be mentioned;

app.lem: Que n'en doie dire le non,
app.rdg: I must say the names

app.lem: E quel roi es terres regnerent,
app.rdg: And which kings ruled in the lands
When they grew and became populated.
I will tell you everything about
Peoples with different appearances.
After that, I will continue the history

app.lem: E tot en ordene vos dirai,
app.rdg: And tell you everything in order:
How Nineveh was founded
And Babylon rebuilt

app.lem: Qui dont fu la dame dou monde;
app.rdg: Which was, at that time, mistress of the world;
Of the second Babylon
Which is now called Damiete

app.lem: Sor le flum siet qui vient d'Egypte,
app.rdg: And lies on the river which comes from Egypt,
And who founded Ebbatanin.

app.lem: Si com je le truis ou latin

app.rdg: I will tell it to the best of my ability

app.lem: Le vos dirai a mon pooir.

app.rdg:
Just as I found it in Latin.
This is a reference to the sources used by the author to compile this history.
And after I will let you know
Everything about Thebes;
I will tell you where Jerusalem is situated,

app.lem: Ce dirai je e en quel terre,
app.rdg: And in which land;

app.lem: Qui le funda, qui li fist guerre.
app.rdg: Who founded it, and who made war against it.
And after this I would like to describe

app.lem: De Troies tot le grant afaire,
app.rdg: All the great events of Troy:

app.lem: Qui le funda, en quel contrée
app.rdg: Who founded it, in which land,

app.lem: E por quoi fu Troie apelée,
app.rdg: And why it was called Troy;

app.lem: Qui le destruist et que devindrent
app.rdg: Who destroyed it and what became

app.lem: Cil qui la vile grant tens tindrent.
app.rdg: Of those who held the city for so long.
Afterwards I will tell you the whole

app.lem: De la veraie estoire de Rome,
app.rdg: Of the true history of Rome:

app.lem: Qui les murs en funda e fist
app.rdg: Who founded and built the walls

app.lem: E les lois premerains i mist.
app.rdg: And imposed the first laws;
I will tell you all the work
Of the great barons, the judges,
The consuls and the senators.
After that the work won’t be small
When it comes to the emperors
Who achieved great honours,

app.lem: Par quoi la cités fu cremue
app.rdg: On account of which the city was feared
And fell into great pride.
For, the Latin attests to this,

app.lem: Toz li mons fu a Rome aclins,
app.rdg: All the world bowed to Rome
When Caesar Augustus ruled.
Afterwards the history will continue

app.lem: Tot si com France fu puplée
app.rdg: With how France was populated

app.lem: E de quel gent fu abitée;
app.rdg: And which people inhabited it.

app.lem: Puis vos voudrai le tens descrire
app.rdg: Then I would like to describe for you the time
In which Our Lord was born on earth,
And how he was crucified —
That will not be passed over in silence —

app.lem: E com au tiers jor suscita
app.rdg: And how on the third day he rose from the dead
And freed his friends from hell,
And how, on the day of Ascension
He rose to his great house,
And how the the apostles
Were instructed and enlightened

app.lem: Dou saint Esperit et de sa grace,
app.rdg: By the Holy Spirit and its grace,
And afterwards, to what distances
They departed from one another and separated

app.lem: E par trestot le munt errerent
app.rdg: And wandered all over the world
To announce the new law

app.lem: Qui mout par est saintisme e bele.
app.rdg: Which is most holy and beautiful.
I will tell you the truth of their lives
According to the source;
Where they preached, where they died,

app.lem: Com firent bien que fere durent.
app.rdg: How they did what they had to do, and did it well.
I will tell you truthfully about the saints - the women and the men -

And I will tell you
As noted above, 'raison’ can mean both what is true and what is just. Here, it is translated as 'truthfully' (see l.205).
Under which rulers they received their deaths.

app.lem: As comans Deu se tindrent fort;
app.rdg: They held fast to God’s commands;
They never abandoned them because of pain

app.lem: Ne por cremor de mort procheine.
app.rdg: Or the fear of imminent death.

app.lem: Tot ce fera mout bon oïr,
app.rdg: All of this will be very good to listen to,
And one should rejoice
When one hears the miracles
With which God glorified their actions.
Lords, it will be right to tell
Of the emperors, one after another:
Who was the first to be christianised
And be called a good Christian,

Reborn in the holy font;
As above, this is a reference to the Christian sacrament of baptism.
When the persecutions ended

app.lem: De ceus qui la loi Deu tenoient
app.rdg: Of those who kept God’s law

app.lem: E lui e ses ovres amoient.
app.rdg: And loved him and his works.
It will be right to tell this fully and
Without any delays.
And then [to tell], without pausing,

app.lem: Qui premerains fu rois de France
app.rdg: Who the first king of France was
To be made Christian, what his name was,
And of his descendants:
Who they were, how they built
The great churches that they founded.
Afterwards, it will be told all together

app.lem: Coment le Wandele, Got e Hun
app.rdg: How the Vandals, Goths and Huns
Pillaged and devastated France
And robbed the churches;

app.lem: E des Normans vos iert retrait
app.rdg: And you will have an account of the Normans

app.lem: E lor conqueste e lor fait,
app.rdg: And their conquest and their deeds:
How they destroyed Germany,
Cologne and prosperous France,
Anjou, Poitou, and all of Burgundy;

app.lem: De ce ne rest il nul doute
app.rdg: That there is no doubt
That the Vandals invaded Flanders

app.lem: E mout de maus ne lor feïssent.
app.rdg: And did them many wrongs.

app.lem: De quels gens Flandres fu puplée
app.rdg: The history of the peoples who populated Flanders
Will be well told for you:

app.lem: Com se proverent, quel il furent,
app.rdg: How they proved themselves, who they were,

app.lem: Com il fierent que fere durent,
app.rdg: How they did what was necessary.
All of this will be described for you,

app.lem: Tot si a point e tot a trait,
app.rdg: Everything at the right moment and at the right pace

So that anyone who wants to hear the truth
As noted above, 'raison’ can mean both what is true and what is just.
Will find little to criticise.

app.lem: L'uevre iert mout bone et delitable
app.rdg: The work will be very good and agreeable

And composed of history without any fiction;
Perhaps unsurprisingly, this line has often been quoted in work on medieval historiography. The word ‘fable’ can mean an invention, a lie, or vain speech, and has been variously interpreted by historians.

app.lem: Por ce iert plaisans et creüe

app.rdg: And because it has grown from truth,
It will be pleasing and will be believed.
The truth is good to hear,
listen to, remember and learn.
Whoever loves and keeps the truth
Is keeping the commands of God.

app.lem: Je n'i veull fors verité dire.
app.rdg: I do not want to say anything but truth.

app.lem: Longue en iert assés la matire
app.rdg: The content will be quite long

app.lem: Qu'en pensée ai contier a plain
app.rdg: That I have in mind to tell in full

To please the Chatelain
'Chatelain' is a medieval French title given to the lord of a castle or fortified place.
Of Lille, Roger, my lord;

app.lem: Cui Deus doint santé et honor,
app.rdg: May God give him health and honour,
Joy and, in the end, Paradise.

app.lem: S'il veut, en romans dou latin

app.rdg: In accordance with his wishes, I plan to translate the entire text

app.lem: Li cuic si traire lonc la letre

app.rdg:
From Latin into the vernacular,
The word used is ‘romans’, which can refer either to the vernacular (contrasted with Latin), or to French in particular (contrasted with other vernacular languages).

app.lem: Que plus ne mains n'i sera metre,
app.rdg: And will not put in any more or less

app.lem: Por qu'envie m'en laist en pais,
app.rdg: So that envy,

app.lem: Qui a maint home kierche fais
app.rdg: Which is a burden to many a man, leaves me in peace.
Lords, envy is an evil thing
That scarcely ever rests:

app.lem: Tempre ne tart ne main ne soir
app.rdg: Neither early nor late, neither morning nor evening

app.lem: Ni li lait il le pais avoir.
app.rdg: Does it let him have peace.

app.lem: Cuers enveious n'iert ja a eise,
app.rdg: An envious heart will never be at ease;

app.lem: Poi voit onques qui bien li plais;
app.rdg: It will scarcely ever see something that truly pleases it.

app.lem: Ne ja d'enveious plus ne mains

app.rdg: I do not intend to say

app.lem: Ne quier plus dire, mais lontains

app.rdg: Any more or less about the envious, but

app.lem: Ne soit il ja ens en sa vie.
app.rdg:
In one’s life they are never far away.
The subject is singular in the original (‘the envious man’).

app.lem: De parlier d'eus n'ai nulle envie.
app.rdg: I have no desire to speak about them.

app.lem: Deus les ament qui le puet fere.
app.rdg: God reforms them, for he is able.
I wish to turn to the history.
So I will say, whoever would like to hear it
Can listen and learn.
